Configuration.StudyNameEntrez: NIH Exome Sequencing of Familial Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis Project
Configuration.StudyNameReportPage: NIH Exome Sequencing of Familial Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis Project
Configuration.Description:
The purpose of this project was to perform exome sequencing of DNA samples obtained from patients diagnosed with familial amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) to search for the genetic factors that predispose to this fatal neurodegenerative disease. Understanding the genetic architecture of familial ALS will provide fundamental insight into the cellular processes that lead to motor neuron death, facilitate animal and in vitro disease modeling, and will provide focus for research aimed at developing therapies that alter the natural course of the disease.

Samples were collected from patients diagnosed with familial ALS in the United States, Italy, Germany, Finland and Israel. Relevant clinical data was collected for each patient, including age of onset, site of symptom onset, gender, and survival. Exome sequencing was performed in the Laboratory of Neurogenetics, National Institute on Aging, National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, MD using a variety of exome capture technologies and next generation sequencing on the Illumina sequence-by-synthesis platform.
Configuration.StudyInEx:
Inclusion criteria

  • Diagnosed as having familial amyotrophic lateral sclerosis by a neurologist.
  • Onset of symptoms after 18 years of age.
  • Non-Hispanic Caucasian ethnicity.

Exclusion Criteria

  • Diagnosis of another condition that could mimic amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.
  • Onset of symptoms before 18 years of age.
  • Non-Caucasian ethnicity.

Publications.Publication: <Journal authors="Janel O. Johnson, Erik P. Pioro, Ashley Boehringer, Ruth Chia, Howard Feit, Alan E. Renton, Hannah A. Pliner, Yevgeniya Abramzon, Giuseppe Marangi, Brett J. Winborn, J Raphael Gibbs, Michael A. Nalls, Sarah Morgan, Maryam Shoai, John Hardy, Alan Pittman, Richard W. Orrell, Andrea Malaspina, Katie C. Sidle, Pietro Fratta, Matthew B. Harms, Robert H. Baloh, Alan Pestronk, Conrad C. Weihl, Ekaterina Rogaeva, Lorne Zinman, Vivian E. Drory, Giuseppe Borghero, Gabriele Mora, Andrea Calvo, Jeffrey D. Rothstein, ITALSGEN, Carsten Drepper, Michael Sendtner, Andrew B. Singleton, J. Paul Taylor, Mark R. Cookson, Gabriella Restagno, Mario Sabatelli, Robert Bowser, Adriano Chiò, Bryan J. Traynor." title="Mutations in the Matrin 3 gene cause familial amyotrophic lateral sclerosis" journal="Nature Neuroscience; 2014;17: epub ahead of print."/>

Configuration.StudyHistory: Case cohort exome sequencing data of n=247 subjects were submitted to dbGaP in December 2013. Additional phenotype and genotype data of genome-wide association studies of ALS may be viewed and accessed through releases of previous study versions (phs000101.v3.p1; phs000101.v2.p1; phs000101.v1.p1)

ConsentGroup.longName: Subjects did not participate in the study, did not complete a consent document and are included only for the pedigree structure and/or genotype controls, such as HapMap subjects

DacInfo.DacFullName: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

ParticipantSet.UseLimitation: Use of the data is limited only by the terms of the model Data Use Certification. These data will be used only for research purposes. They will not be used to determine the individual identity of any person or their relationship to another person.

Document.DisplayName: MOTOR NEURON DISORDERS CLINICAL DATA ELEMENTS
Document.Description: MOTOR NEURON DISORDERS CLINICAL DATA ELEMENTS

Document.OrigName: two stage GWAS of sporadic ALS.pdf
Document.DisplayName: A two-stage genome-wide association study of sporadic amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
Document.Description: A two-stage genome-wide association study of sporadic amyotrophic lateral sclerosis

Analysis.Description: This analysis of association between genotype and the amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) disease status defined by EL Escorial diagnostic criteria was computed by Traynor's group. It contained 276 cases and 271 neurologically normal controls which were derived from the NINDS Neurogenetics repository at Coriell Cell Repositories. The genotyping data was generated and provided by the laboratory of Dr. Andrew Singleton, NIA, Dr. Bryan J. Traynor, NINDS, and Dr. John Hardy, NIA using the Illumina Infinium II HumanHap240S, Infinium II HumanHap300 and Infinium II HumanHap550v1 chips (NIH Intramural funding from NIA and NINDS, additional funding from the ALS Association and the Packard Center for ALS Research at Johns Hopkins).
Analysis.Method: Tests for Association Using Cochran-Armitage Test on Genotype Frequencies
